newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Pakistan rupee seen gradually losing value.
newsitem.headline: Pakistan rupee seen gradually losing value.

text.p: The Pakistani rupee, adjusted downwards on Saturday, is likely to slide gradually in the next few months due to weak economic fundamentals and a strong dollar, analysts said.
The State (central) Bank of Pakistan (SBP) moved the rupee down to 40.4600/40.6623 to the dollar from 40.3900/40.5920 fixed on May 23. It did not explain its action.
Most bankers said it was a technical adjustment made necessary by the dollar's surge against most major currencies.
Some said the rate change had been expected as it was in line with the government's policy of periodically adjusting the rupee's value to keep Pakistani exports competitive.
The rupee has now lost 15.26 percent of its dollar value since the begining of fiscal 1996/97 (July-June), compared to a depreciation of 13.2 percent in the year-ago period.
It was the SBP's fourth depreciation since Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif's government came to power in February.
"We expect a creeping downward adjustment of about 0.10 to 0.12 rupee against the dollar every month till December," one banker said.
The central bank has pursued a crawling peg depreciation policy to match the rupee to a basket of currencies.
Pervaiz Shahbaz, a foreign exchange dealer at Banque IndoSuez, said depreciation was inevitable because of Pakistan's economic woes.
"When you have inflation running at 11 to 12 percent, then a one percent devaluation becomes necessary every month," he said.
But he said minor technical depreciation of the rupee would not help to stimulate exports or make them more competitive.
"Past experience shows it has not helped because to boost exports, the product's quality is a must, not just its price."
Pakistan's trade deficit soared to $254 million in May compared $148 million in the corresponding period a year ago.
Bankers said the rupee's slide was no surprise in view to the widening trade gap and a rising dollar.
Abdullah Ahmed of Bank of America said Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz was fulfilling his promise that there would be no major devaluation till September.

"The government will go for a gradual depreciation of the rupee and we see at least a five percent devaluation of the Pakistani currency in the coming months because the economy has not improved, nor has the growing trade deficit been checked."
"All the banks are running long dollar positions to hedge against rupee depreciation," he said, adding that depreciation was the government's handiest weapon in its export drive.
Shahbaz said the government would be reluctant to order a sharp devaluation because of its harsh social consequences.
"Pakistan is an import-oriented country and prices of daily commodities would soar, which would be a highly unpopular step for the government," he said.
Bankers said the IMF wanted the government to maintain a realistic rupee exchange rate, making it likely that small downward adjustments would continue.
An International Monetary Fund mission is expected in Islamabad early next month to start talks on a new medium-term loan from the IMF's enhanced structural adjustment facility.

Owais Kalia, a money changer, said the rupee would remain under pressure in the kerb market on fears that the SBP would keep depreciating it. "But in the near term, the dollar could take a dip on profit-taking," he said.
